With a bare fricace of your med'cine: still,
You increase your friends.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: I, 'tis very pregnant.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: And, then, the turning of this Lawyers pewter
To plate, at Christ-masse—

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: Christ-tide, I pray you.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yet, ANANIAS?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: I haue done.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Or changing
His parcell guilt, to massie gold. You cannot
But raise you friends. With all, to be of power
To pay an armie, in the field, to buy
The king of France, out of his realmes; or Spaine;
Out of his Indies: What can you not doe,
Against lords spirituall, or temporall,
That shall oppone you?

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Verily, 'tis true.
We may be temporall lords, our selues, I take it.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: You may be any thing, and leaue off to make
Long-winded exercises: or suck vp,
Your ha, and hum, in a tune. I not denie,
But such as are not graced, in a state,
May, for their ends, be aduerse in religion,
And get a tune, to call the flock together:
For (to say sooth) a tune do's much, with women,
And other phlegmatick people, it is your bell.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: Bells are prophane: a tune may be religious.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: No warning with you? Then, farewell my patience.
'Slight, it shall downe: I will not be thus tortur'd.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: I pray you, sir.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: All shall perish. I haue spoke it.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Let me find grace, sir, in your eyes; the man
He stands corrected: neither did his zeale
(But as your selfe) allow a tune, some-where.
Which, now, being to'ard the stone, we shall not need.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: No, nor your holy vizard, to winne widdowes
To giue you legacies; or make zealous wiues
To rob their husbands, for the common cause:
Nor take the start of bonds, broke but one day,
And say, they were forfeited, by prouidence.
Nor shall you need, ore-night to eate huge meales,
To celebrate your next daies fast the better:
The whilst the Brethren, and the Sisters, humbled,
Abate the stiffenesse of the flesh. Nor cast
Before your hungrie hearers, scrupulous bones,
As whether a Christian may hawke, or hunt;
Or whether, Matrons, of the holy assembly,
May lay their haire out, or weare doublets:
Or haue that idoll Starch, about their linnen.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: It is, indeed, an idoll.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Mind him not, sir.
I doe command thee, spirit (of zeale, but trouble)
To peace within him. Pray you, sir, goe on.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Nor shall you need to libell 'gainst the Prelates,
And shorten so your eares, against the hearing
Of the next wire-drawne grace. Nor, of necessitie,
Raile against playes, to please the Alderman,
Whose daily custard you deuoure. Nor lie
With zealous rage, till you are hoarse. Not one
Of these so singular arts. Nor call your selues,
By names of TRIBVLATION, PERSECVTION,
RESTRAINT, LONG-PATIENCE, and such like, affected
By the whole family, or wood of you,
Onely for glorie, and to catch the eare
Of the Disciple.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Truely, sir, they are
Wayes, that the godly Brethren haue inuent'd
For propagation of the glorious cause,
As very notable meanes, and whereby, also,
Themselues grow soone, and profitably famous.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: O, but the stone, all's idle to'it! nothing!
The art of Angels, Natures miracle,
The diuine secret, that doth flye in clouds,
From east to west: and whose tradition
Is not from men, but spirits.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: I hate Traditions:
I do not trust them—

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: They are Popish, all.
I will not peace. I will not—

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: ANANIAS.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: Please the prophane, to grieue the godly: I may not.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Well, ANANIAS, thou shalt ouer-come.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: It is an ignorant zeale, that haunts him, sir.
But truely, else, a very faithfull Brother,
A botcher: and a man, by reuelation,
That hath a competent knowledge of the truth.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Has he a competent summe, there, i' the bagg,
To buy the goods, within? I am made guardian,
And must, for charitie, and conscience sake,
Now, see the most be made, for my poore orphane:
Though I desire the Brethren, too, good gayners.
There, they are, within. When you haue view'd, & bought'hem,
And tane the inuentorie of what they are,
They are readie for proiection; there's no more
To doe: cast on the med'cine, so much siluer
As there is tinne there, so much gold as brasse,
I'll gi'it you in, by waight.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: But how long time,
Sir, must the Saints expect, yet?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Let me see,
How's the moone, now? Eight, nine, ten dayes hence
He will be siluer potate; then, three dayes,
Before he citronise: some fifteene dayes,
The Magisterium will be perfected.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: About the second day, of the third weeke,
In the ninth month?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yes, my good ANANIAS.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: What will the orphanes goods arise to, thinke you?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Some hundred markes; as much as fill'd three carres,
Vnladed now: you'll make sixe millions of 'hem.
But I must ha' more coales laid in.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Another load,
And then we ha' finish'd. We must now encrease
Our fire to ignis ardens, we are past
Fimus equinus, Balnei, Cineris,
And all those lenter heats. If the holy purse
Should, with this draught, fall low, and that the Saints
Doe need a present summe, I haue trick
To melt the pewter, you shall buy now, instantly,
And, with a tincture, make you as good Dutch dollers,
As any are in Holland.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Can you so?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I, and shall bide the third examination.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: It will be ioyfull tidings to the Brethren.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: But you must carry it, secret.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: I, but stay,
This act of coyning, is it lawfull?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: Lawfull?
We know no Magistrate. Or, if we did,
This's forraine coyne.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: It is no coyning, sir.
It is but casting.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Ha? you distinguish well.
Casting of money may be lawfull.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: 'Tis, sir.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: Truely, I take it so.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: There is no scruple,
Sir, to be made of it; beleeue ANANIAS:
This case of conscience he is studied in.

sp.speaker: TRI.
sp.l: I'll make a question of it, to the Brethren.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: The Brethren shall approue it lawfull, doubt not.
Where shall't be done?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: For that wee'll talke, anone.
Knock without. There's some to speake with me. Goe in, I pray you,
And view the parcells. That's the inuentorie.
I'll come to you straight. Who is it? FACE! Appeare.
HOw now? Good prise?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Good poxe! Yond' caustiue cheater
Neuer came on.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: How then?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I ha' walk'd the round,
Till now, and no such thing.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: And ha' you quit him?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Quit him? and hell would quit him too, he were happy.
'Slight would you haue me stalke like a mill-iade.
All day, for one, that will not yeeld vs graines?
I know him of old.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: O, but to ha' gull'd him,
Had beene a maistry.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Let him goe, black Boy,
And turne thee, that some fresh newes may possesse thee.
A noble Count, a Don of Spaine (my deare
Delicious compeere, and my partie-bawd)
Who is come hether, priuate, for his conscience,
And brought munition with him, sixe great slopps,
Bigger then three Dutch hoighs, beside round trunkes,
Furnish'd with pistolets, and pieces of eight,
Will straight be here, my rogue, to haue thy bath
(That is the colour,) and to make his battry
Vpon our DOL, our Castle, our cinque-Port,
Our Douer pire, our what thou wilt. Where is shee?
Shee must prepare perfumes, delicate linnen,
The bath in chiefe, a banquet, and her wit,
For shee must milke his Epididimis.
Where is the Doxie?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I'll send her to thee:
And but dispatch my brace of little IOHN LEYDENS,
And come againe my selfe.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Are they within then?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Numbring the summe.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: How much?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: A hundred marks, Boy.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Why, this's a lucky day! Ten pounds of MAMMON!
Three o' my clarke! A portague o' my grocer!
This o' the Brethren! beside reuersions,
And states, to come i' the widdow, and my Count!
My share, to day, will not be bought for fortie—

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Pounds, daintie DOROTHEE, art thou so neere?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Yes, say lord Generall, how fares our campe?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: As, with the few, that had entrench'd themselues
Safe, by their discipline, against a world, DOL:
And laugh'd, within those trenches, and grew fat
With thinking on the booties, DOL, brought in
Daily, by their small parties. This deare houre,
A doughtie Don is taken, with my DOL;
And thou maist make his ransome, what thou wilt,
My Dousabell: He shall be brought here, fetter'd
With thy faire lookes, before he see's thee; and throwne
In a downe-bed, as darke as any dungeon;
Where thou shalt keepe him waking, with thy drum;
Thy drum, my DOL; thy drum; till he be tame
As the poore black-birds were i' the great frost,
Or bees are with a bason: and so hiue him
I' the swan-skin couerlid, and cambrick sheets,
Till he worke honey, and waxe, my little Gods-guift.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: What is he, Generall?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: An Adalantado,
A Grande, girle. Was not my DAPPER here, yet?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Nor my DRVGGER?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: A poxe on 'hem.
They are so long a furnishing! Such stinkards
Would not be seene, vpon these festiuall dayes.
How now! ha' you done?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Done. They are gone. The summe
Is here in banque, my FACE. I would, we knew
Another chapman, now, would buy 'hem outright.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: 'Slid, NAB shall do't against he ha' the widdow,
To furnish houshold.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Excellent, well thought on:
Pray God he come.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I pray he keepe away
Till our new business be o're-past.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: But, FACE,
How cam'st thou, by this secret Don?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: A spirit
Brought me th' intelligence, in a paper, here,
As I was conjuring yonder in my circle
For SVRLY; I ha' my flies abroad. Your bath
Is famous, SVBTLE, by my means. Sweet DOL,
You must go tune your virginall, no loosing
O' the least time. And, doe you heare? good action.
Firke, like a flounder; kisse, like a scallop, close:
And tickle him with thy mother-tongue. His great
VERDVGO-ship has not a iot of language;
So much the easier to be cossined, my DOLLY
He will come here in a hir'd coach, obscure,
And our owne coach-man, whom I have sent, as guide,
No creature else. One knocks Who's that?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: It i' not he?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: O no, not yet this hour.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Who is't?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Dapper,
Your Clarke.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: God's will then, Queene of Faerie,
On with your tyre; and, Doctor, with your robes.
Let's dispatch him for gods sake.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: 'Twill be long.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I warrant you, take but the cues I give you,
It shall be briefe inough. 'Slight, here are more!
ABEL, and I think the angrie boy, the heire,
That faine would quarrel.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: And the widdow?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: No,
Not that I see. Away! O sir, you are welcome.
THe Doctor is within, a mouing for you;
(I haue had the most adoe to winne him to it)
He sweares, you'll be the dearling o'the dice:
He neuer heard her Highnesse dote, till now (he sayes.)
Your aunt has giu'n you the most gracious words,
That can be thought on.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: Shall I see her Grace

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: See her, and kisse her, too. What? honest NAB!
Ha'st brought the damaske?

sp.speaker: NAB.
sp.l: No, sir, here's tabacco

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: 'Tis well done, NAB: Thou'lt bring the damaske too?

sp.speaker: DRV.
sp.l: Yes, here's the gentleman, Captaine, master KASTRIL,
I haue brought to see the Doctor.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Where's the widdow?

sp.speaker: DRV.
sp.l: Sir, as he likes, his sister (he sayes) shall come.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: O, is it so? 'good time. Is your name KASTRIL, sir?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: I, and the best o' the KASTRILS, I'lld be sorry else,
By fifteene hundred, a yeere. Where is this Doctor?
My mad tabacco-Boy, here, tells me of one
That can doe things. Has he any skill?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Wherein, sir?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: To carry a businesse, manage a quarrel, fairely,
Vpon fit termes.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: It seemes, sir, yo' are but young
About the towne, that can make that question!

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Sir, not so yong, but I haue heard some speech
Of the angrie Boyes, and seene 'hem take tabacco;
And in his shop: and I can take it too.
And I would faine be one of 'hem, and goe downe
And practise i' the countrey.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Sir, for the Duello,
The Doctor, I assure you, shall informe you,
To the least shaddow of a haire: and shew you,
An instrument he has, of his owne making,
Where-with, no sooner shall you make report
Of any quarrel, but he will take the height on't,
Most instantly; and tell in what degree,
Of saf'ty it lies in or mortalitie.
And, how it may be borne, whether in a right line,
Or a halfe-circle; or may, else, be cast
Into an angle blunt, if not acute:
All this he will demonstrate. And then, rules,
To giue and take the lie, by.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: How? to take it?
Yes, in oblique, hee'll shew you; or in circle
But neuer in diameter. The whole towne
Studies hi theoremes, and dispute them, ordinarily,
At the eating Academies.
But, do's he teach
Liuing, by the wits, too?
Any thing, what euer.
You cannot thinke that subtiltie, but he reades it.
He made me a Captaine. I was a starke pimpe,
Iust o' your standing, 'fore I met with him:
It is not two months since. I'll tell you his method.
First, he will enter you, at some ordinarie.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: No, I'll not come there. You shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: For why, sir

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: There's gaming there, and tricks.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Why would you be
A gallant, and not game?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: I, 'twill spend a man.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Spend you? It will repair you, when you are spent.
How doe they liue by their wits, there, that haue vented
Sixe times your fortunes?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: What, three thousand a yeere!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I, fortie thousand

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Are there such?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I, sir
And gallants, yet. Here's a yong gentleman,
Is borne to nothing, fortie markes a yeere,
Which I count nothing. H'is to be initiated,
And haue a flye o'the Doctor. He will winne you
By vnresistable lucke, within this fortnight,
Inough to buy a baronie. They will set him
Vpmost, at the Groome-porters, all the Christmasse!
And, for the whole yeere through, at euerie place,
Where there is play, present him with the chaire;
The best attendance, the best drinke, sometimes
Two glasses of canarie, and pay nothing;
The purest linnen, and the sharpest knife,
The partrich next his trencher: and, somewhere,
The daintie bed, in priuate, with the daintie.
You shall ha' your ordinaries bid for him,
As play-houses for a poet; and the master
Pray him, aloud, to name what dish he affects,
Which must be butterd shrimps: and those that drinke
To no mouth else, will drinke to his, as being
The goodly, president mouth of all the boord.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Doe you not gull one?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: 'Od's my life! Do you thinke it?
You shall haue a cast commander, (can but get
In credit with a glouer, or a spurrier,
For some two paire, of eithers ware, afore-hand)
Will, by most swift posts, dealing with him,
Arriue at competent meanes, to keepe himselfe,
His punke, and naked boy, in excellent fashion.
And be admir'd for't.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Will the Doctor teach this?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: He will doe more, sir, when your land is gone,
(As men of spirit hate to keepe earth long (
In a vacation, when small monie is stirring,
And ordinaries suspended till the tearme,
Hee'll shew a perspectiue, where on one side
You shall behold the faces, and the persons
Of all sufficient yong heires, in towne,
Whose bonds are currant for commoditie;
On th'other side, the marchants formes, and others,
(That, without helpe of any second broker,
(Who would expect a share) will trust such parcels:
In the third square, the verie street, and signe
Where the commoditie dwels, and do's but wait
To be deliuer'd, be it pepper, sope,
Hops, or tabacco, oat-meale, woad, or cheeses.
All which you may so handle, to enioy,
To your owne vse, and neuer stand oblig'd.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: I'faith! Is he such a fellow?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Why, NAB here knowes him.
And then for making matches, for rich widdowes,
Yong gentlewomen, heyres, the fortunat'st man!
Hee's sent too, farre, and neere, all ouer England,
To haue his counsell, and to know their fortunes.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Gods will, my suster shall see him.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I'll tell you, sir,
What he did tell me of NAB. It's a strange thing!
(By the way you must eate no cheese, NAB, it breeds melancholy:
And that same melancholy breeds wormes) but passe it,
He told me, honest NAB, here, was ne'er at tauerne,
But once in's life!

sp.speaker: DRV.
sp.l: Truth, and no more I was not.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: And, then he was so sick—

sp.speaker: DRV.
sp.l: Could he tell you that, too?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: How should I know it?

sp.speaker: DRV.
sp.l: In troth we had beene a shooting,
And had a piece of fat ram-mutton, to supper,
That lay so heauy o' my stomack—

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: And he has no head
To beare any wine; for, what with the noise o' the fiddlers,
And care of his shop, for he dares keepe no seruants—

sp.speaker: DRV.
sp.l: My head did so ake—

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: As he was faine to be brought home,
The Doctor told me. And then, a good old woman—

sp.speaker: DRV.
sp.l: (Yes faith, shee dwells in Sea-coale-lane) did cure me,
With sodden ale, and pellitorie o' the wall:
Cost me but two pence. I had another sicknesse,
Was worse then that.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I, that was with the griefe
Thou took'st for being sess'd at eighteene pence,
For the water-worke.

sp.speaker: DRV.
sp.l: In truth, and it was like
T'haue cost me almost my life.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Thy haire went off?

sp.speaker: DRV.
sp.l: Yes, sir, 'twas done for spight.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Nay, so sayes the Doctor.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Pray thee, tabacco-Boy, goe fetch my suster,
I'll see this learned Boy, before I goe:
And so shall shee.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Sir, he is busie now:
But, if you haue a sister to fetch hether,
Perhaps, your owne paines may command her sooner;
And he, by that time, will be free.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: I goe.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: DRVGGER, shee's thine: the damaske. (SVBTLE, and I
Must wrastle for her.) Come on, master DAPPER.
You see, how I turne clients, here, away,
To giue your cause dispatch. Ha'you perform'd
The ceremonies were inioyn'd you?

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: Yes, o' the vinegar,
And the cleane shirt.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: 'Tis well: that shirt may doe you
More worship then you thinke. Your aunt's a fire
But that shee will not shew it, t'haue a sight on you.
Ha'you prouided for her Graces seruants?

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: Yes, here are sixe-score EDWARD shillings.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: And an old HARRY'S soueraigne.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Very good.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: And three IAMES shillings, and an ELIZABETH groat,
Iust twentie nobles.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: O, you are too iust.
I would you had had the other noble in MARIES.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: I haue some PHILIP, and MARIES.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I, those same
Are best of all. Where are theuy? Harke, the Doctor.

div.head: ACT III, Scene V.
div.stage: Subtle disguis'd like a Priest of Faery

sp.l: Is yet her Graces cossen come?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: He is come.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: And is he fasting?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Yes

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: And hath cry'd hum?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Thrise, you must answer.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: Thrise

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: And as oft buz?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: If you haue, say.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: I haue.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Then, to her cuz,
Hoping, that he hath vinegard his senses,
As he was bid, the Faery Queene dispenses,
By me, this robe, the petticote of FORTUNE;
Which that he straight put on, shee doth importune.
And though to FORTUNE neere be her petticote
Yet, neerer is her smock, the Queene doth note:
And, therefore, euen of that piece shee hath sent,
Which, being a child, to wrap him in, was rent;
And prayes him, for a scarfe, he now will weare it
(With as much loue, as then her Grace did teare it)
sp.stage: They blind him with a rag.
sp.l: About his eyes, to shew, he is fortunate.
And, trusting vnto her to make his state,
He'll throw away all wordly pelfe, about him;
Which that he will performe, shee doth not doubt him.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Shee need not doubt him, sir. Alas, he has nothing,
But what he will part withall, as willingly,
Vpon her Graces word (throw away your purse)
As shee would aske it: (handkerchiefs, and all)
Shee cannot bid that thing, but hee'll obay.
(If you haue a ring, about you, cast it off,
sp.stage: He throwes away, as they bid him.
sp.l: Or a siluer seale, at your wrist, her Grace will send
Her Faeries here to search you, therefore deale
Directly with her Highnesse. If they find
That you conceale a mite, you are vn-done.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: Truely, there's all.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: All what?

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: My money, truly

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Keep nothing, that is transitorie, about you.
sp.stage: Dol enters with a cittern: they pinch him
sp.l: (Bid DOL play musique.) Looke, the Elues are come
To pinch you, if you tell not truth. Aduise you.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: O, I haue a paper with a spur-ryall in't.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: They knew't, they say.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Ti, ti, ti, ti, he has more yet.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Ti, ti-ti-ti. I'the other pocket?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: They must pinch him, or he will neuer confessse, they say.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: O, ô

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Nay, 'pray you hold. He is her Graces nephew.
Ti, ti, ti? What care you? Good faith, you shall care.
Deale plainly, sir, and shame the Faeries. Shew
You are an innocent.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: By this good light, I ha' nothing.

sp.speaker: SVB
sp.l: Ti ti, tititota. He do's equiuocate, shee sayes:
Ti, ti do ti, ti ti do, ti da. And sweares by the light, when he is blinded.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: By this good darke, I ha' nothing but a halfe-crown
Of gold, about my wrist, that my loue gaue me;
And a leaden heart I wore, sin' shee forsooke me.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I thought, 'twas something. And, would you incurre
Your aunts displeasure for these trifles? Come,
I had rather you had throwne away twentie halfe-crownes.
You may weare you leaden heart still. How now?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: What newes. DOL?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Yonder's your knight, sir MAMMON.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Gods lid, we neuer thought of him, till now.
Where is he?

sp.speaker: DOL
sp.l: Here, hard by. H'is at the doore.

sp.speaker: SVB
sp.l: And, you are not readie, now? DOL, get his suit.
He must not be sent back.

sp.speaker: FAC..
sp.l: What shall we doe with this same Puffin, here,
Now he's o' the spit?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Why, lay him back a while,
With some deuice. Ti, ti ti, ti ti ti. Would her Grace speake with me?
I come. Helpe, DOL.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Who's there? Sir EPICURE;
sp.stage: He speakes through the key-hole, the other knocking.
sp.l: My master's i'the way. Please you to walke
Three or foure turnes, but till his back be turn'd,
And I am for you. Quickly, DOL.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Her Grace
Commends her kindly to you, master DAPPER.

sp.speaker: DAP.
sp.l: I long to see her Grace.
She, now, is set
At dinner, in her bed; and shee has sent you,
From her owne priuate trencher, a dead mouse,
And a piece of ginger-bread, to be merry withall,
And stay your stomack, lest you faint with fasting:
Yet, if you could hold out, till shee saw you (shee sayes)
It would be better for you.

sp.speaker: FAC
sp.l: Sir, he shall
Hold out, and 'twere this two houres, for her Highnesse;
I can assure you that. We will not loose
All we ha' done—

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: He must nor see, nor speake
To any body, till then.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: For that, wee'll put, sir,
A stay in'is mouth.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Of ginger-bread
Make you it fit. He that hath pleas'd her Grace,
Thus farre, shall not now crinckle, for a little.
Gape sir, and let him fit you.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Where shall we now
Bestow him?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: I'the priuie.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Come along, sir,
I now must shew you Fortunes priuy lodgings.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Are they perfum'd? and his bath readie?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: All.
Only the Fumigation's somewhat strong.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Sir EPICVRE. I am yours, sir, by and by
O, Sir, yo'are come i' the onely, finest time—

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Where's master?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Now preparing for proiection, sir.
Your stuffe will b' all chang'd shortly.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Into gold?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: To gold, and siluer, sir.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Siluer, I care not for.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Yes, sir, a little to giue beggars.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Where's the lady?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: At hand, here. I ha' told her such braue things, o' you,
Touching your bountie and your noble spirit—

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Hast thou?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: As shee is almost in her fit to see you.
But, good sir, no diuinitie i' your conference,
For feare of putting her in rage—

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Sixe men will not hold her downe. And, then
If the old man should heare, or see you—

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Feare not.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: The very house, sir, would runne mad. You know it
How scrupulous he is, and violent,
'Gainst the least act of sinne. Physick, or Mathematiques,
Poetrie, State, or Bawdry (as I told you)
Shee will endure, and neuer startle: But
No word of controuersie.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: I am school'd, good Ulen.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: And you must praise her house, remember that,
And her nobilitie.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Let me, alone:
No Herald, no nor Antiquarie, Lungs,
Shall doe it better. Goe.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Why, this is yet
A kind of moderne happinesse, to haue
DOL Common for a great lady.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Now, EPICVRE,
Heighten thy selfe, talke to her, all in gold;
Raine her as many showers, as IOVE did drops
Vnto his DANAE: Shew the God a miser,
Compar'd with MAMMON. What? the stone will do't.
Shee shall feele gold, tast gold, heare gold, sleepe gold:
Nay, we will concumbere gold. I will be puissant,
And mightie in my talke to her! Here shee comes.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: To him, DOL, suckle him. This is the noble knight,
I told your ladiship—

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Madame, with your pardon,
I kisse your vesture.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Sir, I were vn-ciuill
If I would suffer that, my lip to you, sir.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: I hope, my lord your brother be in health, lady?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: My lord, my brother is, though I no ladie, sir.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: (Well said my Guiny-bird.)

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Right noble madame—

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: (O, we shall haue most fierce idolatrie!)

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: 'Tis your prerogatiue.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Rather your courtesie.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Were there nought else t'inlarge your vertues, to me,
These answeres speake your breeding, and your bloud.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Bloud we boast none, sir, a poore Baron's daughter.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Poore! and gat you? Prophane not. Had your father
Slept all the happy remnant of his life
After that act, lyen but there still, and panted,
H' had done inough, to make himselfe, his issue,
And his posteritie noble.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Sir, although
We may be said to want the guilt, and trappings,
The dresse of honor; yet we striue to keepe
The seedes, and the materialls.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: I doe see
The old ingredient, vertue, was not lost,
Nor the drug money, vs'd to make your compound.
There is a strange nobilitie, i' your eye,
This lip, that chin! Me thinks you doe resemble
One o' the Austriack princes.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Very like,
Her father was an Irish costar-monger.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: The house of Valois, iust, had such a nose.
And such a fore-head, yet, the Medici
Of Florence boast.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Troth, and I haue beene lik'ned
To all these Princes.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I'll be sworne, I heard it.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: I know not how! it is not any one,
But ee'n the very choise of all their features.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I'll in, and laugh.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: A certaine touch, or aire,
That sparkles a diuinitie, beyond
An earthly beautie!

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: O, you play the courtier.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Good lady, gi' me leaue—

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: In faith, I may not,
To mock me, sir.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: To burne i' this sweet flame:
The Phoenix neuer knew a nobler death.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Nay, now you court the courtier: and destroy
What you would build. This art, sir, i' your words,
Calls your whole faith in question.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: By my soule—

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Nay, oathes are made o' the same aire, sir.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Nature
Neuer bestow'd vpon mortalitie,
A more vnblam'd, a more harmonious feature:
Shee play'd the step-dame in all faces, else.
Sweet madame, le' me be particular—

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Particular, sir? I pray you, know your distance.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: In no ill sense, sweet lady, but to aske
How your faire graces passe the houres? I see
Yo'are lodg'd, here, i' the house of a rare man,
An excellent Artist: but, what's that to you?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Yes, sir. I studie here the mathematiques,
And distillation.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: O, I crie your pardon.
H' is a diuine instructer! can extract
The soules of all things, by his art; call all
The vertues, and the miracles of the Sunne,
Into a temperate fornace: teach dull nature
What her owne forces are. A man, the Emp'rour
Has courted, aboue KELLEY: sent his medalls,
And chaines, t'inuite him.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: I, and for his physick, sir——

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Aboue the art of AESCVLAPIVS,
That drew the enuy of the Thunderer
I know all this, and more.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Troth, I am taken, sir,
Whole, with these studies, that contemplate nature:

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: It is a noble humour. But, this forme
Was not intended to so dark a vse!
Had you beene crooked, foule, of some course mould,
A cloyster had done well: but, such a feature
That might stand vp the glorie of a kingdome,
To liue recluse! is a mere solaecisme,
Though in a nunnery. It must not be.
I muse, my lord your brother will permit it!
You should spend halfe my land first, were I hee.
Do's not this diamant better, on my finger,
Then in the quarrie?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Why, you are like it.
You were created, lady, for the light!
Heare, you shall weare it; take it, the first pledge
Of what I speake: to bind you to beleeue me.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: In chaines of adamant?

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Yes, the strongest bands.
And take a secret, too. Here, by your side,
Doth stand, this houre, the happiest man, in Europe.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: You are contented, sir?

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Nay, in true being:
The enuy of Princes, and the feare of States.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Say you so, sir EPICVRE!

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Yes, & thou shalt proue it,
Daughter of honor. I haue cast mine eye
Vpon thy forme, and I will reare this beautie
Aboue all stiles.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: You meane no treason, sir!

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: No, I will take away that iealousie.
I am the lord of the Philosophers stone,
And thou the lady.

sp.speaker: DOL
sp.l: How sir! ha' you that?

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: I am the master of the maistrie.
This day, the good old wretch, here, o' the house
Has made it for vs. Now, hee's at proiection.
Thinke therefore, the first wish, now; let me heare it:
And it shall raine into thy lap, no shower,
But flouds of gold, whole cataracts, a deluge,
To get a nation on thee!

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: You are pleas'd, sir,
To worke on the ambition of our sexe.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: I am pleas'd, the glorie of her sexe should know,
This nooke, here, of the Friers, is no climate
For her, to liue obscurely in, to learne
Physick, and surgery, for the Constables wife
Of some odde Hundred in Essex; but come forth,
And tast the aire of palaces; eate, drinke
The toyles of Emp'ricks, and their boasted practice;
Tinctured of pearle, and corrall, gold, and amber;
Be seene at feasts, and triumphs; haue it ask'd,
What miracle shee is? set all the eyes
Of court a-fire, like a burning glasse,
And worke 'hem into cinders; when the iewells
Of twentie states adorne thee; and the light
Strikes out the starres; that, when thy name is mention'd
Queenes may looke pale: and, we but shewing our loue,
NERO's POPPAEA may be lost in storie!
Thus, will we haue it.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: I could well consent, sir.
But, in a monarchy, how will this be?
The Prince will soone take notice; and both seize
You, and your stone: it being a wealth vnfit
For any priuate subiect.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: If he knew it.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Your selfe doe boast it, sir.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: To thee, my life.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: O, but beware, sir! You may come to end
The remnant of your daies, in a loth'd prison,
By speaking of it.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: 'Tis no idle feare!
Wee'll therefore goe with all, my girle, and liue
In a free state; where we will eate our mullets,
Sous'd in high-countrey wines, sup pheasants egges,
And haue our cockles, boild in siluer shells,
Our shrimps to swim againe, ass when they liu'd,
In rare butter, made of dolphins milke,
Whose creame do's looke like opalls: and, with these
Delicate meats, set our seluves high for pleasure,
And take vs downe again, and then renew
Our youth, and strength, with drinking the elixir,
And so enjoy a perpetuitie
Of life, and lust. And thou shalt ha' thy wardrobe,
Richer than Natures, still, to change thy selfe
And vary oftner, for thy pride, then shee:
Or Art, her wise, and almost-equall seruant.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Sir, you are too loud. I heare you, euery word,
Into the labarotory. Some fitter place.
The garden, or great chamber aboue. How like you her?

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Excellent! Lungs. There's for thee.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: But, doe you heare?
Good sir, beware, no mention of the Rabbines.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: We thinke not on 'hem.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: O, it is well, sir. SVBTLE!
DOst thou not laugh?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yes. Are they gone?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: All's cleare.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: The widdow is come.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: And your quarrelling disciple?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I must to my Captaine-ship againe, then.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Stay, bring 'hem in, first.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: So I meant. What is shee?
A Bony-bell?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Wee'll draw lots,
You'll stand to that?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: What else?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: O, for a suite,
To fall now, like a cortine: flap.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: To th'dore, man.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: You'll ha' the first kisse, 'cause I am not readie.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yes, and perhaps hit you through both the nostrils.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Who would you speak with?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Wher's the Captaine?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Gone, sir,
About some businesse.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Gone?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Hee'll returne straight.
But master Doctor, his Lieutenant, is here.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Come neere, my worshipfull Boy, my terrae Fili,
That is, my Boy of land; make thy approches:
Welcome, I know thy lusts, and thy desires,
And I will serue, and satisfie 'hem. Beginne,
Charge me from thence, or thence, or in this line;
Here is my center: Ground thy quarrell.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: You lie.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: How, child of wrath, and anger! the loud lie?
For what, my sodaine Boy?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Nay, that looke you too,
I am afore-hand.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: O, this's no true Grammar,
And as ill Logick! You must render causes, child,
Your first, and second Intentions, know your canons,
And your diuisions, moodes, degrees, and differences,
Your praedicaments, substance, and accident,
Series externe, and interne, with their causes
Efficient, materiall, formall, finall,
And ha' your elements perfect—

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: What is this!
The angrie tongue he talkes in?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: That false precept,
Of being afore-hand, has deceiu'd a number;
And made 'hem enter quarrells, often-times,
Before they were aware: and, afterward,
Against their wills.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: How must I doe then, sir?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I crie this lady mercy. Shee should, first,
Haue beene saluted. I doe call you lady,
Because you are to be one, ere't be long,
He kisses her. My soft, and buxome widdow.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Is shee, i-faith?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yes, or my art is an egregious lyar.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: How know you?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: By inspection, on her fore-head,
And subtiltie of her lip, He kisses her againe. which must be tasted
Often, to make a iudgement. 'Slight, shee melts
Like a Myrobalane! Here is, yet, a line
In riuo frontis, tells me, he is no knight.

sp.speaker: PLI.
sp.l: What is he then, sir?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Let me see your hand.
O, your linea Fortunae makes it plaine;
And stella, here, in monte Veneris:
But, most of all, iunctura annularis.
He is a souldier, or a man of art, lady:
But shall haue some great honour, shortly.

sp.speaker: PLI.
sp.l: Brother,
Hee's a rare man, beleeue me!

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Hold your peace.
Here comes the tother rare man. 'Save you Captaine.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Good master KASTRIL. Is this your sister?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: I, sir.
Please you to kusse her, and be proud to know her?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I shall be proud to know you, ladie.

sp.speaker: PLI.
sp.l: Brother,
He calls me ladie, too.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: I, peace. I heard it.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: The Count is come.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: At the dore.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Why, you must entertaine him.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: what'll you doe
With these the while?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Why, haue 'hem vp, and shew 'hem
Some fustian booke, or the darke glasse.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: 'Fore god,
Shee is a delicate dab-chick! I must haue her.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Must you? I, if your fortune will, you must.
Come sir, the Captaine will come to vs presently.
I'll ha' you to my chamber of demonstrations,
Where I'll shew you both the Grammar, and Logick,
And Rhetorick of quarrelling; my whole method,
Drawne out in tables: and my instrument,
That hath the seuerall scale vpon't, shall make you
Able to quarrell, at a strawes breadth, by Moone-light.
And, lady, I'll haue you looke in a glasse,
Some halfe an houre, but to cleare your eye-sight,
Against you see your fortune: which is greater,
Then I may iudge vpon the sodaine, trust me.
WHere are you, Doctor?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I'll come to you presently.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I will ha' this same widdow, now I ha' seene her,
On any composition.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: What doe you say?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Ha' you dispos'd of them?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I ha' sent 'hem vp.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: SVBTLE, in troth, I needs must haue this widdow.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Is that the matter?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Nay, but heare me.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Goe to,
If you rebell once, DOL shall know it all.
Therefore, be quiet, and obey your chance.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Nay, thou art so violent now—— Doe but conceive:
Thou art old, and canst not serue——

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Who, cannot I?
'Slight, I will serue her with thee, for a——

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Nay,
But vnderstandL I'll gi' you composition.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I will not treat with thee: what, sell my fortune?
'Tis better then my birth-right. Doe not murmure.
Winne her, and carrie her. If you grumble, DOL
Knowes it directly.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Well sir, I am silent.
Will you goe helpe, to fetch in Don, in state?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I follow you, sir: we must keepe FACE in awe,
Or he will ouer-looke vs like a tyranne.
Braine of a taylor! Who comes here? Don Ion!

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Sennores, besolas manos, à vuestras mercedes.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Would you had stoup'd a little, and kist our anos.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Peace SVBTLE.

sp.speaker: SVB
sp.l: Stab me; I shall neuer hold, man.
He lookes in that deepe ruffe, like a head in a platter,
Seru'd in by a short cloake vpon two tressils!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Or, what doe you say to a collar of brawne, cut downe
Beneath the souse, and wriggled with a knife?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: 'Slud, he do's looke too fat to be a Spaniard.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Perhaps some Fleming, or some Hollander got him
In D'ALVA's time: Count EGMONTs bastard.

sp.speaker: SVB/
sp.l: Don
Your sciruy, yellow, Madrid face is welcome.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: He speakes, out of a fortification.
'Pray god, he ha' no squibs in those deepe sets.

sp.speaker: SVR
sp.l: Por dios, Sennores, muy linda casa

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: What sayes he?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Praises the house, I thinke,
I know no more but's action.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yes, the Casa
My precious DIEGO, will prooue faire inough,
To cossen you in. Doe you marke? you shall
Be cossened, DIEGO.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Cossened, doe you see?
My worthy Donzel, cossened.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Doe you intend it? So doe we, deare Don.
Haye you brought pistolets? or portagues?
My solemne Don? Dost thou feele any?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Full.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: You shall be emptied, Don; pumped, and drawne,
Drie, as they say.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Milked, in troth, sweet Don.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: See all the monsters; the great lyon of all, Don.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Con licencia, se puede ver à esta Sennor à?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: What talkes he now?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: O' the Sennora.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: O, Don,
That is the lyonesse, which you shall see
Also, my Don.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: 'Slid, SVBTLE, how shall we doe?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: For what?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Why, DOL's emploi'd, you know.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: That's true!
For heau'n I know not: He must stay, that's all.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Stay? That he must not by no meanes

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: No, why?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Vnlesse you'll marre all. 'Slight, hee'll suspect it.
And then he will not pay, not halfe so well.
This is a trauvell'd punque-master, and do's know
All the delayes: a notable hot raskall,
And lookes, already, rampant.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: 'Sdeath, and MAMMON
Must not be troubled.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: MAMMON, in no case.

sp.speaker: SVB
sp.l: What shall we doe then?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Thinke: you must be sodaine.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.p: Entiendo, que la Sennora es tan hermosa, que codìcio tan à ver la, come la bien auentur'ança de mi vida.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Mi vida? 'Slid, SVBTLE, he puts me in minde o'the widow.
What dost thou say to draw her to't? ha?
And tell her, it is her fortune. All our venter
Now lies vpon't. It is but one man more,
Which on's chance to haue her: and, beside,
There is no maiden-head, to be fear'd, or lost.
What doest thou thinke on't, SVBTLE?

sp.speaker: SVBTLE.
sp.l: Who, I? Why——

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: The credit of our house too is engag'd.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: You made me an offer for my share e're while.
What wilt thou gi'me, i'faith?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: O, by that light,
Ile not buy now. You know your doome to me.
E'en take your lot, obey your chance, sir; winne her,
And weare her, out for me.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: 'Slight. I'll not worke her then.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: It is the common cause, therefore bethinke you.
DOL else must know it, as you said.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I care not.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Sennores, por que se tarda tanta?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Faith, Iam not fit, I am old.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: That's now no reason, sir.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Puede ser, de hazer burla de mi amor.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: You heare the Don, too? By this ayre, I call.
And loose the hinges, DOL.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: A plague of hell——

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Will you then doe?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yo'are a terrible rogue,
Ile thinke of this: will you, sir, call the widow?
Yes, and Ile take her too, with all her faults,
Now I doe thinke on't better.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: With all my heart, sir,
Am I discharg'd o'the lot?

sp.speaker: FAC
sp.l: As you please.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Hands.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Remember now, that vpon any change,
You neuer claime her.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Much good ioy, and health to you, sir.
Marry a whore? Fate, let me wed a witch first.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Por estas hoxrada's barbas——

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: He sweares by his beard.
Dispatch, and call the brother too.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Tienge dùda, Sennores,
Que no me h'agan alguna traycion.

sp.speaker: SVB/
sp.l: How, issue on? Yes, praestoSennor. Please you
Enthratha the chambratha, worthy Don;
Where if it please the Fates, in your bathada,
YOu shall be sok'd, and strok'd and tub'd, and rub'd;
And scrub'd, and fub'd, deare Don, before you goe.
You shall, in faith, my sciruie babioun Don:
Be curried, claw'd, and flaw'd, and taw'd, indeed.
I will the heartilier goe about it now,
And make the widdow a punke, so much the sooner,
To be reueng'd on this impetuous FACE:
The quickly doing of it is the grace.

div.head: Act IIII. Scene IIII.
div.stage: FACE, KASTRIL, DA. PLIANT, SVBTLE, SVRLY.

sp.l: COme ladie: I knew, the Doctor would not leaue,
Till he had found the very nick of her fortune.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: To be a Countesse, say you? A Spanish Countesse, sir.

sp.speaker: PLI.
sp.l: Why? is that better then an English Countesse?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Better? 'Slight, make you that a question, ladie?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Nay, shee is a foole, Captaine, you must pardon her.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Aske from your courtier, to your innes of court-man,
To your mere millaner: they will tell you all,
Your Spanish iennet is the best horse. Your Spanish
Stoupe is the best garbe. Your Spanish beard
Is the best cut. Your Spanish ruffes are the best
Weare. Your Spanish Pauin the best daunce.
Your Spanish titillation in a gloue
The best perfume. And, for your Spanish pike,
And Spanish blade, let your poore Captaine speake.
Here comes the Doctor.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: My most honor'd ladie,
(For so I am now to stile you, hauing found
By this my scheme, you are to vnder-goe
An honorable fortune, very shortly.)
What will you say now, if some—

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I ha' told her all, sir.
And her right worshipfull brother, here, that shee shall be
A Countesse: doe not delay 'hem, sir. A Spanish Countesse.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Still, my scarse worshipfull Captaine, you can keepe
No secret. Well, since he has told you, madame,
Doe you forgiue him, and I doe.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Shee shall doe that, sir.
I'le looke to't, 'tis my charge.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Well then. Nought rests
But that shee fit her loue, now, to her fortune.

sp.speaker: PLI.
sp.l: Truely, I shall neuer brooke a Spaniard.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: PLI.
sp.l: Neuer, sin' eighty-eight could I abide 'hem,
And that was some three yeere afore I was borne, in truth.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Come, you must loue him, or be miserable:
Choose, which you will.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: By this good rush, perswade her,
Shee will crie straw-berries else, within this twelue-month.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Nay, shads, and mackrell, which is worse.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Indeed, sir?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Gods lid, you shall loue him, or Ile kick you.

sp.speaker: PLI.
sp.l: Why?
Ile doe as you will ha' me, brother.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Doe,
Or by this hand, I'll maull you.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Nay, good sir,
Be not so fierce.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: No, my enraged child,
Shee will be rul'd. What, when shee comes to tast
The pleasures of a Countesse! to be courted—

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: And kist, and ruffled!

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I, behind the hangings.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: And then come forth in pomp!

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: And know her state!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Of keeping all th'idolaters o' the chamber
Barer to her, then at their prayers!

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Is seru'd
Vpon the knee!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: And has her pages, huishers,
Foot-men, and coaches—

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Her sixe mares—

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Nay, eight!

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: To hurry her through London, to th'Exchange,
Bet'lem, the China-houses—

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Yes, and haue
The citizens gape at her, and praise her tyres!
And my-lords goose-turd bands, that rides with her!

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Most braue! By this hand, you are not my suster,
If you refuse.

sp.speaker: PLI.
sp.l: I will not refuse, brother.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Que es esto, Sennores, que non se venga?
Esta tardanza me mata!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: It is the Count come!
The Doctor knew he would be here, by his art.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: En gallanta Madama, Don! gallantissima!

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Por tódos los dioses, la mas acabada
Hermosura, que he visto en mi vida!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Is't not a gallant language, that they speake?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: An admirable language! Is't not French?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: No, Spanish, sir.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: It goes like law-French,
And that, they say, is the court-liest language.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: List, sir.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: El Sol ha perdido su lumbre, con el
Resplandor, que tràe esta dama. Valga me dios!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: He'admires your sister.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Must not shee make curtsie?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: 'Ods will, shee must goe to him, man; and kisse him!
It is the Spanish fashion, for the women
To make first court.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: 'Tis true he tells you, sir:
His art knowes all.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Por que no se acùde?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: He speakes to her, I thinke?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: That he do's sir.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Por el amor de dios, que es esto, que se tàrda?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Nay, see: shee will not vnderstand him! Gull.
Noddy.

sp.speaker: PLI.
sp.l: What say you brother?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Asse, my suster,
Goe kusse him, as the cunning man would ha' you,
I'll thrust a pinne i' your buttocks else.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: O, no sir.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Sennora mia, mi persona muy indigna esta
Alle gar à tànta Hermosura.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Do's he not vse her brauely?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Brauely, i-faith!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Nay, he will vse her better.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Doe you think so?

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Sennora, sie sera seruida, entremus.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Where do's he carry her?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Into the garden, sir;
Take you no thought: I must interpret for her.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Giue DOL the word. Come, my fierce child, aduance,
We'll to our quarrelling lesson againe.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Agreed.
I loue a Spanish Boy, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Nay, and by this meanes, sir, you shall be brother
To a great Count.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: I. I lknew that, at first.
This match will aduance the house of the KASTRILS.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: 'Pray god, your sister proue but pliant.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Why,
Her name is so: by her other husband.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: How

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: The widdow PLIANT. Knew you not that?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: No faith, sir.
Yet, by erection of her figure, I gest it.
Come, let's goe practice.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Yes, but doe you thinke, Doctor,
I e'er shall quarrell well?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I warrant you.
For, after ALEXANDERs death——

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Good lady——

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: That PERDICCAS, and ANTIGONVS were slaine,
The two that stood, SELEVC' and PTOLOMEEE—

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Madame.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Made up the two legs, and the fourth Beast.
That was Gog-north, and Egypt-south: which after
Was call'd Gog Iron-leg, and South Iron-leg——

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Lady——

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: And then Gog-horned. So was Egypt, too.
Then Egypt clay-leg, and Gog clay-leg——

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Sweet madame.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: And last Gog-dust, and Egypt-dust, which fall
In the last linke of the fourth chaine. And these
Be starres in story, which none see, or looke at——

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: What shall I doe?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: For, as he sayes, except
We call the Rabbines, and the heathen Greekes——

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Dear lady

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: To come from Salem, and from Athens,
And teach the people of great Britaine——

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: What's the matter, sir?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: To speake the tongue of EBER, and IAVAN——

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: O,
Sh'is in her fit

sp.speaker: DOL
sp.l: We shall know nothing——

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Death, sir,
We are vn-done.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Where, then, a learned Linguist
Shall see the antient vs'd communion
Of vowels, and consonants——

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: My master will heare!

sp.speaker: DOL
sp.l: A wisedome, which PYTHAGORAS held most high——

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Sweet honorable lady.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: To comprise
All sounds of voyces, in few markes of letters——

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Nay, you must neuer hope to lay her now.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: And so we may arriue by Talmud skill,
And profane greeke, to raise the building vp
Of HELENs house against the Ismaelite,
King of Thogarma, and Habergions
Brimstony, blew, and fiery; and the force
Of King Abaddon, and the Beast of Cittim:
Which Rabbi DAVID KIMCHI, ONKELOS,
And ABEN- EZRA doe interpret Roma.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: How did you put her into it?

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Alas, I talk'd
Of a fift Monarchy I would erect,
With the Philosophers stone (by chance) and she
Fals on the other foure, straight.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Out of Broughton.
I told you so. 'Slid stop her mouth.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Is't best?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: She'll neuer leaue else. If the old man heare her
We are but faeces, ashes.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: What's to doe there?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: O, we are lost. Now she heares him, she is quiet.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Where shall I hide me?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: How! What sight is here?
Close deeds of darknesse, and that shunne the light!
Bring him againe. Who is he? What, my sonne!
O, I haue liu'd too long.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Nay good, deare father,
There was no'vnchast purpose.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Not? and flee me,
When I come in?

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: That was my error.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Error?
Guilt, guilt, my sonne. Giue it the right name. No maruaile,
If I found check in our great worke within,
When such affaires as these were managing!

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Why, haue you so?

sp.speaker: SVB
sp.l: It has stood still this halfe houre:
And all the rest of our lesse workes gone back.
Where is the instrument of wickednesse,
My lewd false drudge?

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Nay, good sir, blame not him.
Beleeue me, 'twas against his will, or knowledge.
I saw her by chance.

sp.speaker: SVB
sp.l: Will you commit more sinne,
T'excuse a varlet?

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: By my hope, 'tis true, sir.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Nay, then I wonder lesse, if you, for whom
The blessing was prepar'd, would so tempt heauen:
And loose your fortunes.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Why, sir

sp.speaker: SVB
sp.l: This'll retard
The worke, a month at least.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Why, if it doe,
What remedie? but thinke it not, good father:
Our purposes were honest.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: As they were,
sp.stage: A great crack and noise within.
sp.l: So the reward will proue. How now! Aye me.
God, and all Saints be good to vs. What's that?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: O sir, we are defeated! all the workes
Are flowne in fumo: euery glasse is burst.
Fornace, and all rent downe! as if a bolt
Of thunder had beene driuen through the house.
Retorts, Receiuers, Pellicanes, Bolt-heads
All strooke in shiuers! Helpe, good sir! Alas,
sp.stage: Subtle falls downe as ina swoune.
sp.l: Coldnesse and death inuades him. Nay, sir MAMMON,
Doe the fair offices of a man! You stand,
As you were readier to depart, then he.
Who's there? My lord her brother is come.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Ha, Lungs?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: His coach is at the dore. Auoid his sight,
For hee's as furious, as his sister is mad.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: My braine is quite vn-done with the fume, sir,
I ne'er must hope to be mine owne man againe.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Is all lost, Lungs? Will nothing be preseru'd,
Of all our cost?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Faith, very little, sir.
A peck of coales, or so, which is cold comfort, sir.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: O my voluptuous mind! I am iustly punish'd.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: And so am I, sir.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Cast from all my hopes—

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Nay, certainties, sir.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: By mine owne base affections.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Subtle seemes come to himselfe. O, the curst fruits of vice, and lust!

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Good father,
It was my sinne. Forgiue it.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Hangs my roofe
Ouer vs still, and will not fall, Ô iustice,
Vpon vs, for this wicked man!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Nay, looke, sir,
You grieue him, now, with staying in his sight:
Good sir, the noble man will come too, and take you,
And that may breed a tragoedie.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: I'll goe.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I, and repent at home, sir. It may be,
For some good penance, you may ha'it, yet,
A hundred pound to the boxe at Bet'lem—

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: For the restoring such as ha' their wits.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: I'll do't.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Ile send one to you to receiue it.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Doe.
Is no proiection left?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: All flowne, or stinks, sir.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Will nought be sau'd, that's good for med'cine, thinkst thou?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I cannot tell, sir. There will be, perhaps,
Something, about the scraping of the shardes,
Will cure the itch: though not your itch of mind, sir.
It shall be sau'd for you, and sent home. Good sir,
This way: for feare the lord should meet you.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: FACE.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Is he gone?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Yes, and as heauily
As all the gold he hop'd for, were in his bloud.
Let vs be light, though.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I, as balls, and bound
And hit our heads against the roofe for ioy:
There's so much of our care now cast away.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Now to our Don.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yes, your yong widdow, by this time
Is made a Countesse, FACE: Sh' has beene in trauaile
Of a yong heire for you.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Good, sir.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Off with your case,
And greet her kindly, as a bride-groome should,
After these common hazards.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Very well, sir.
Will you goe fetch Don DIEGO off, the while?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: And fetch him ouer too, if you'll be pleas'd, sir:
Would DOL were in her place, to pick his pockets now.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Why, you can doe it as well, if you would set to't.
I pray you proue your vertue.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: For your sake, sir.
LAdy, you see into what hands, you are falne;
Mongst what a nest of villaines! and how neere
Your honor was t'haue catch'd a certaine clap
(Through your credulitie) had I but beene
So punctually forward, as place, time,
And other circumstance would ha' made a man:
For yo'are a handsome woman: would yo' were wise, too.
I am a gentleman, come here disguis'd,
Onely to find the knaueries of this Citadell,
And where I might haue wrong'd your honor, and haue not,
I claime some interest in your loue. You are,
They say, a widdow, rich: and I am a batcheler,
Worth nought: Your fortunes may make me a man,
As mine ha' preseru'd you a woman. Thinke vpon it,
And whether, I haue deseru'd you, or no.

sp.speaker: PLI.
sp.l: I will, sir.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: And for these houshold-rogues, let me alone,
To treat with them.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: How doth my noble DIEGO?
And my deare madame, Countesse? Hath the Count
Beene courteous, lady? liberall? and open?
Donzell, me thinkes you looke melancholike,
After your coitum, and scuruy! True-ly,
I doe not like the dulnesse of your eye:
It hath a heauy cast, 'tis vpsee Dutch,
And say's you are a lumpish whore-master.
Be lighter, He falls to picking of them. I will make your pockets so.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Will you, Don bawd, and pick-purse? How now? Reele you?
Stand vp sir, you shall find since I am so heauy,
I'll gi' you equall weight.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Helpe, murder!

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: No, sir.
There's no such thing intended. A good cart,
And a cleane whip shall ease you of that feare.
I am the Spanish Don, that should be cossened,
Doe you see? cossened? Where's your Captayne FACE?
That parcell-broker, and whole-bawd, all raskall.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: How, SVRLY!

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: O, make your approach, good Captaine.
I'haue found, from whence your copper rings, and spoones
Come, now, wherewith you cheate abroad in tauernes.
'Twas here, you learn'd t'anoint your boot with brimstone,
Then rub mens gold on't, for a kind of touch,
And say 'twas naught, when you had chang'd the colour,
That you might ha't for nothing? And this Doctor,
Your sooty, smoakie-bearded compeere, he
Will close you so much gold, in a bolts-head,
And, on a turne, conuay (i'the stead) another
With sublim'd Mercurie, that shall burst i'the heate,
And flye out all in fumo? Then weepes MAMMON;
Then swounes his worship. Or, he is the FAVSTVS,
That casteth figures, and can coniure, cures
Plague, piles, and poxe, by the Ephemerides,
And holds intelligence with all the bawdes,
And midwiues of three shires? while you send in——
Captaine, (what is he gone?) dam'sells with child,
Wiues, that are barren, or, the waiting-maide
With the greene-sicknesse? Nay, sir, you must tarrie
Though he be scap't; and answere, by the eares, sir.

div.head: Act IIII. Scene VII.
div.stage: FACE, KASTRIL, SVRLEY, SUBTLE, DRVGGER, ANANIAS, DA. PLAINT, DOL.

sp.l: WHy. now's the time, if euer you will quarrell
Well (as they say) and be a true-borne child.
The Doctor, and your sister both are abus'd.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Where is he? which is he? he is a slaue
What ere he is, and the sonne of a whore. Are you
The man, sir, I would know?

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: I should be loth, sir,
To confesse so much.

sp.speaker: KAS
sp.l: Then you lie, i' your throate.

sp.speaker: SVR
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: A very errant rogue, sir, and a cheater,
Employd here, by another coniurer,
That dos not loue the Doctor, and would crosse him
If he knew how——

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Sir, you are abus'd

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: You lie:
And 'tis no matter.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Well said,, sir. He is
The impdent'st raskall——

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: You are indeed. Will you hear me, sir?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: By no means: Bid him be gone.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Be gone, sir, quickly.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: This's strange! Lady, doe you informe your brother.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: There is not such a foyst, in all the towne,
The Doctor had him, presently: and findes, yet,
The Spanish Count will come, here. Beare vp, SVBTLE.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yes, sir, he must appeare, within this hour.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: And yet this rogue, would come, in a disguise
By the temptation of another spirit,
To trouble our art, though he could not hurt it.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: I
I know—— Away, you talke like a foolish mauther.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Sir, all is truth, she saies.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Doe not beleeue him, sir:
He is the lying'st Swabber! Come your wayes, sir.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: You are valiant, out of companie.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Yes, how then, sir?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Nay, here's an honest fellow too, that knowes him,
And all his tricks. (Make good what I say, ABEL,)
This cheater would ha' cossen'd thee o' the widdow.
He owes this honest DRVGGER, here, seuen pound,
He has had on him, in two-penny'orths of tabacco.

sp.speaker: DRV.
sp.l: Yes sir. And h' has damn'd himself, three termes, to pay mee.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: And what do's he owe for lotium?

sp.speaker: DRV.
sp.l: Thirtie shillings, sir:
And for sixe syringes.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: HYDRA of villanie!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Nay, sir you must quarrell him out o' the house.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: I will.
Sir, if you get not out o'dores, you lie:
And you are a pimpe.

sp.speaker: SVR
sp.l: Why, this is madnesse, sir,
Not valure in you: I must laugh at this.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: It is my humour: you are a Pimpe, and a Trig,
And an AMADIS de Gaule, or a Don QUIXOTE.

sp.speaker: DRV.
sp.l: Or a Knight o'the curious cox-combe. Doe you see?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: Peace to the houshold

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Ile keepe peace, for no man.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: Casting of dollers is concluded lawfull.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Is he the Constable?

sp.speaker: SVB
sp.l: Peace, ANANIAS.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: No, sir.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Then you are an Otter, and a Shad, a whit,
A very Tim.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: You'll heare me, sir?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: I will not.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: What is the motiue?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Zeale, in the yong gentleman,
Against his Spanish slops——

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: They are profane,
Leud, superstitious, and idolatrous breeches.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: New raskals!

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Will you be gone, sir?

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: Auoid Sathan,
Thou are not of the light. That ruffe of pride,
About thy neck, betrays thee: 'and is the same
With that, which the vncleane birds, in seuenty-seven,
Were seene to pranke it with, on diuers coasts.
Thou look'st like Antichrist, in that leud hat.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: I must giue way.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Be gone, sir.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: But Ile take
A course with you——

sp.speaker: (ANA.
sp.l: Depart, proud Spanish fiend.

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Captain, & Doctor——

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: Child of perdition.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Hence, sir.
Did I not quarrel brauely?

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Yes, indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: Nay, and I giue my mind to't, I shall do't.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: O, you must follow, sir, and threaten him tame.
Hee'll turne againe else.

sp.speaker: KAS.
sp.l: I'll re-turne him, then.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: DRVGGER,, this rogue preuented vs, for thee:
We'had determin'd, that thou shouldst ha' come,
In a Spanish sute, and ha' carried her so; and he
A brokerly slaue, goes, puts it on himselfe.
Hast brought the damaske?

sp.speaker: DRV.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Thou must borrow,
A Spanish suite. Hast thou no credit with the players?

sp.speaker: DRV.
sp.l: Yes, sir, did you neuer see me play the foole?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I know not, NAB: thou shalt, if I can helpe it.
HIERONYMO'S old cloake, ruffe, and hat will serue,
Subtle hath whisperd with him this while. Ile tell thee more, when thou bringst 'hem.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: Sir, I know
The Spaniard hates the Brethren, and hath spies
Vpon their actions: and that this was one
I make no scruple. But the holy Synode
Haue beene in prayer, and meditation, for it.
And 'tis reueal'd no lesse, to them, then me,
That casting of money is most lawfull.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: True.
But here, I cannot doe it; if the house
Should chance to be suspected, all would out,
And we be lock'd vp, in the tower, for euer,
To make gold there (for th'state) neuer come out:
And, then, are you defeated.

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: I will tell
This to the Elders, and the weaker Brethren,
That the whole companie of the Separation
May ioyne in humble prayer againe.

sp.speaker: (SVB.
sp.l: And fasting.)

sp.speaker: ANA.
sp.l: Yea, for some fitter place. The peace of mind
Rest with these walls.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Thanks, courteous ANANIAS.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: What did he come for?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: About casting dollers,
Presently, out of hand. And so, I told him,
A Spanish minister came here to spie,
Against the faithfull—

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: I conceiue. Come SVBTLE,
Thou art so downe vpon the least disaster!
How wouldst tho' ha' done, if I had not helpt thee out?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: I thanke thee FACE, for the angrie Boy, i-faith.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Who would ha' lookt, it should ha' beene that raskall?
SVRLY? He had dy'd his beard, and all. Well, sir,
Here's damaske come, to make you a suit.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Where's DRVGGER?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: He is gone to borrow me a Spanish habite,
Ile be the Count, now.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: But where's the widdow?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Within, with my lords sister: Madame DOL
Is entertayning her.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: By your fauour, FACE,
Now shee is honest, I will stand againe.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: You will not offer it?

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Stand to your word,
Or— here comes

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: She knowes—

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yo'are tyrannous still.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Strict for my right. How now, DOL? Hast'told her,
The Spanish Count will come?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Yes, but another is come,
You little look'd for!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Your master:
The master of the house.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: How, DOL!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Shee lies.
This is some trick. Come, leaue your quiblins, DOROTHEE.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Looke out, and see.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Art thou in earnest?

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: 'Slight,
Fortie o' the neighbours are about him, talking.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: 'Tis he, by this good day.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: 'Twill proue ill day,
For some on vs.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: We are vndone, and taken.

sp.speaker: DOL.
sp.l: Lost, I'am afraid.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: You said he would not come,
While there dyed one a weeke, within the liberties.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: No: 'twas within the walls.

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Was't so? Cry' you mercy:
I thought the liberties. What shall we doe now, FACE?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Be silent: not a word, if he call, or knock.
I'll into mine old shape againe, and meet him,
Of IEREMIE, the butler. I' the meane time,
Doe you two pack vp all the goods, and purchase,
That we can carry i'the two trunkes. I'll keepe him
Off for to day, if I cannot longer: and then
At night, Ile ship you both away to Ratcliffe,
Where wee'll meet to morrow, and there wee'll share.
Let MAMMON'S brasse, and pewter keepe the cellar:
Wee'll haue another time for that. But, DOL,
'Pray thee, goe heate a little water, quickly,
SVBTLE must shaue me. All my Captaines beard
Must off, to make me appeare smooth IEREMIE.
You'll do't?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: Yes, Ile shaue you, as well as I can.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: And not cut my throte, but trim me?

sp.speaker: SVB.
sp.l: You shall see, sir.
HAs there beene such resort, say you?

sp.speaker: NEI. 1.
sp.l: Daily, sir.

sp.speaker: NEI. 2.
sp.l: And nightly, too.

sp.speaker: NEI. 3.
sp.l: I, some as braue as lords.

sp.speaker: NEI. 4.
sp.l: Ladies, and gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: NEI. 5.
sp.l: Citizens wiues.

sp.speaker: NEI. 1.
sp.l: And knights.

sp.speaker: NEI. 6.
sp.l: In coches.

sp.speaker: NEI. 2.
sp.l: Yes, & oyster-women.

sp.speaker: NEI. 1.
sp.l: Beside other gallants.

sp.speaker: NEI. 3.
sp.l: Sailors wiues.

sp.speaker: NEI. 4.
sp.l: Tabacco-men.

sp.speaker: NEI. 5.
sp.l: Another Pimlico!

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: What should my knaue aduance,
To draw this companie? He hung out no banners
Of a strange Calfe, with fiue legs, to be seene?
Or a huge Lobster, with sixe clawes?

sp.speaker: NEI. 6.
sp.l: No, sir.

sp.speaker: NEI. 3.
sp.l: We had gone in then, sir.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: He has no guift
Of teaching i'the nose, that ere I knew of!
You saw no Bills set vp, that promis'd cure
Of agues, or the tooth-ach?

sp.speaker: NEI. 2.
sp.l: No such thing, sir.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Nor heard a drum strooke, for Babiouns, or Puppets?

sp.speaker: NEI. 5.
sp.l: Neither, sir.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: What deuice should he bring forth now!
I loue a teeming wit, as I loue my nourishment.
'Pray god he ha' not kept such open house,
That he hath sold my hangings, and my bedding:
I left him nothing else. If he haue eate 'hem,
A plague o' the moath, say I. Sure he has got
Some bawdy pictures, to call all this ging;
The Frier, and the Nun; or the new Motion
Of the Knights courser, couering the Parsons mare;
The Boy of sixe yeere old, with the great thing;
Or 'tmay be, he has the Fleas that runne at tilt,
Vpon a table, or some Dog to daunce?
When saw you him?

sp.speaker: NEI. 1.
sp.l: Who sir, IEREMIE?

sp.speaker: NEI. 2.
sp.l: IEREMIE butler?
We saw him not this month.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: NEI. 4.
sp.l: Not these 5. weeks, sir.

sp.speaker: NEI
sp.l: These six weeks, at the least.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Yo'amaze me, neighbours!

sp.speaker: NEI. 5.
sp.l: Sure, if your worship know not where he is,
Hee's slipt away.

sp.speaker: NEI. 6.
sp.l: Pray god, he be not made away!

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Ha? It's no time to question, then.

sp.speaker: NEI. 6.
sp.l: About
Some three weekes since, I heard a dolefull cry,
And I sate vp, a mending my wives stockings.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: 'Tis strange! that none will answere! Didst thou heare
A cry, saist thou?

sp.speaker: NEI. 6.
sp.l: Yes, sir, like vnto a man
That had beene strangled an houre, and could not speake.

sp.speaker: NEI. 2.
sp.l: I heard it too, iust this day three weekes, at two a clock
Next morning.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: These be miracles, or you make 'hem so!
A man an houre strangled, and could not speake,
And both you heard him cry?

sp.speaker: MNEI. 3.
sp.l: Yes, downeward, sir.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Thou art a wise fellow: Giue me thy hand I pray thee.
What trade art thou on?

sp.speaker: NEI. 3.
sp.l: A smith, and't please your worship.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: A smith? Then, lend me thy helpe, to get this dore open.

sp.speaker: NEI. 3.
sp.l: That I will presently, sir, but fetch my tooles——

sp.speaker: NEI. 1.
sp.l: Sir, best so knock againe, afore you break it.
I will.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: What meane you, sir?

sp.speaker: NEI. 1.2.4.
sp.l: O, here's IEREMIE!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Good sir, come from the dore.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Why! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Yet farder, you are too neere, yet.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: I' the name of wonder!
What meanes the fellow?

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: The house, sir, has beene visited.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: What? with the plague? stand thou then farder.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: No sir,
I had it not.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Who had it then: I left
None else, but thee, i' the house!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Yes, sir. My fellow,
The cat, that kept the buttry, had it on her
A weeke, before I spied it: but I got her
Conuay'd away, i'the night. And so I shut
The house vp for a month——

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Purposing then, sir,
T' haue burnt rose-vinegar, triackle, and tarre,
And, ha' made it sweet, that you should ne'er ha' knowne it:
Because I knew the newes woulld but afflict you, sir.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Breath lesse, and farder off. Why, this is stranger!
The neigbours tell me all, here, that the dores
Haue still been open——

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: How, sir!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Gallants, men, and women,
And of all sorts, tag-rag, beene seene to flock here
In threaues, these ten weekes, ass to a second Hogs-den,
In dayes of Pimlico, and Eye-bright!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Sir,
Their wisedomes will not say so!

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Today, they speake
Of coaches, and gallants; one in a French-hood,
Went in, they tell me: and another was seene
In a veluet gowne, at the windore! diuerse more
Passe in and out!

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: They did passe through the dores then,
Or walls, I assure their eye-sights, and their spectacles;
For here, sir, are the keyes; and here haue beene,
In this my pocket, now, aboue twentie dayes!
And for before, I kept the fort alone, there.
But, that 'tis yet not deepe i' the after-noone,
I should beleeue my neighbours had seene double
Through the black-pot, and made these apparitions!
For, on my faith, to your worship, for these three weekes,
And vpwards, the dore has not beene open'd.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Strange!

sp.speaker: NEI. 1.
sp.l: Good faith, I thinke I saw a coach!

sp.speaker: NEI. 2.
sp.l: And I too,
I'lld ha' been sworne!

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Doe you but thinke it now?
And but one coach?

sp.speaker: NEI. 4.
sp.l: We cannot tell, sir: IEREMIE
Is a very honest fellow.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: Did you see me at all?

sp.speaker: NEI. 1.
sp.l: No. That we are sure on.

sp.speaker: NEI. 2.
sp.l: I'll be sworne o' that.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Fine rogues, to haue your testimonies built on!

sp.speaker: NEI. 3.
sp.l: Is IEREMIE come?

sp.speaker: NEI. 1.
sp.l: O, yes, you may leaue your tooles,
We were deceiu'd, he sayes.

sp.speaker: NEI. 2.
sp.l: He'has had the keyes:
And the dore has beene shut these three weekes.

sp.speaker: NEI. 3.
sp.l: Like enough.

sp.speaker: LOV.
sp.l: Peace, and get hence, you changelings.

sp.speaker: FAC.
sp.l: SVRLY come!
And MAMMON made acquainted? They'll tell all.
How shall I beate them off? What shall I doe?)
Nothing's more wretched, then a guiltie conscience.

div.head: ACT V. Scene III.
div.stage: SVRLY, MAMMON, LOVE- WIT, FACE, NEIGHBOVRS, KASTRIL, ANANIAS, TRIBVLATION, DAPPER, SVBTLE

sp.l: No, sir, he was a great physitian. This
It was no bawdy-house: but a meere Chancell.
You knew the lord, and his sister.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Nay, good SVRLY——

sp.speaker: SVRLY
sp.l: The happy word, be rich——

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Play not the tyranne ———

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: Should be to day pronounc'd, to all your friends.
And where be your andirons now? and your brasse pots?
That should ha' beene golden flaggons, and great wedges?

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Let me but breath. What! They ha' shut their dores,
Mammon and Surly knock. Methinks!

sp.speaker: SVR.
sp.l: I, now, 'tis holy-day with them.

sp.speaker: MAM.
sp.l: Rogues,
Coseners, impostors, bawds.

sp.speaker: FAC.
